etymology.type: phono-semantic compound (also analyzed as ideogrammic compound)
etymology.description: semantic: 氵 ‘water’ + phonetic: 气; alternatively: semantic: 氵 + semantic: 气 ‘air’.
etymology.interpretation: Uses the water component to point to a fluid-related meaning, while the phonetic 气 guides the reading qì. Read ideographically, combining ‘water’ and ‘air’ vividly evokes steam or vapor.

examples.chinese: 杯子上有水汽(杯子上有水汽)。
examples.english: There is water vapor on the cup.

examples.chinese: 早晨的空气里充满了湿润的蒸汽(早晨的空氣裡充滿了濕潤的蒸汽)。
examples.pinyin: Zǎochén de kōngqì lǐ chōngmǎnle shīrùn de zhēngqì.
examples.english: The morning air is filled with moist steam.

examples.chinese: 他打开汽水(他打開汽水)，瓶口冒出白色的汽(瓶口冒出白色的汽)。
examples.pinyin: Tā dǎkāi qìshuǐ, píngkǒu mào chū báisè de qì.
examples.english: He opened the soda, and white vapor came out of the bottle mouth.
